London - England

Much like any capital city, London is really as much a destination for shopping trips as it is for taking inside sights. Whether you're shopping for a bespoke suit from Savile Row or some thing more alternative and unique from Camden Market, London's underground system may well transport you round the city inside of minutes.

Oxford Street is a heaven for high streets shopping, although the crowds and queues can be quite hellish! For a much more upmarket experience, Mayfair or Knightsbridge are both home to most of the big designer names.

London is usually home to Harrods, the world's most famous department store and as much a tourist attraction for a shopping destination. Harrods is probably most famed for the claim that they could obtain "Everything for just anyone, Everywhere" and the subsequent rumour that US President Reagan once ordered a baby elephant from the retail store. If the price looks too good being true, it probably is.

<b> Michael Kors handbags: </b> Michael Kors is known for his trademark square buckles, snaps or accents relating to the handbag. Every Michael Kors purse has these square accessories. The knock-offs do not have these accents or in many cases forget to use the logo to the hardware.

<b> Marc Jacobs shopping bags: </b> Marc Jacobs zippers have slanted "i's". If the bag comes with upright "i's" then it is probably a replica designer. Authentic Marc Jacobs handbags do not have blank zippers. Note that on a number their E/W (East/West) shopping bags a Lampo zipper is going to be used. A Lampo zipper is usually manufactured by Lampo and will have the zipper brand found on the backside or underneath this zipper. I had an interesting experience a few days ago that generated quite a stir in my coffee clutch. I happened to bump to a lady at Starbucks that i had a nodding friend with. I market trend handbags online, and noticed the case she was carrying appeared as if a Louis Vuitton, so that i asked her about the idea. She told me it was eventually a replica designer because your lady couldn't possibly afford a real Louis Vuitton. On closer inspection I observed that signature "LV" was absent from what should have been the trademark habit. I told her it wasn't a classic, but also not some sort of replica designer. It could certainly be a designer inspired bag. Splitting hairs you say, well not necessarily.

Designer inspired is exactly that. Fashion that is generated from another's design, without the intent to help fool one into thinking it's a classic. replica designer, on the other hand, has the deliberate intention to fool one into thinking it's an original. If we accept these definitions, along with the legal community does, it opens up three topics of discussion:

1. Since consumers, we search with regard to designer inspired fashion handbags, shoes and accessories because we love the looks, but not the price tag.
<br> 2. We look for original designer goods, and tend to be fooled into buying replica designers at a very low cost, because we would like an original but can't spend the money for full retail price.
<br> 3. We look for replica designers because we like the prestige of owning an original, but cannot afford the cost.

As for attempting to find designer inspired fashion, there is slight cause for issue. Our culture has a knack for re-defining such a word or phrase may mean. The phrase "shut up" suggests, be quiet or cease talking. However as a colloquialism it indicates "no way" or "you're kidding". "Designer inspired" in a legal sense means a product or service that is inspired by the designer without breaching almost any design patents or active trademarks. The only thing that will seem a little deceitful is that they benefit from all the research and development costs that a designer puts into a product. The expense is essential. As long as the intent is not really to deceive the public into believing your handmade jewelry is an original, there is, as yet, nothing illegal. The replica designer or counterfeit market, however, is trying to grey the definition just by advertising as designer inspired, but producing replica designers.
